questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "FOUNDATION LEVEL : SEMESTER 1: ENGLISH I" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "FOUNDATION LEVEL : SEMESTER 1: ENGLISH I" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.
 My vision for India in the 100th year of its Independence is that of a global innovation leader focused on equitable and inclusive economic growth where everyone prospers in a secure environment with equal access to healthcare, education and sustainable livelihoods. It is by investing in breakthrough ideas and embracing entrepreneurship as an economic model of growth that India will be able to unleash the power of innovation to ensure a better life for all its citizens. Research and innovation, fuelled by technology, will catalyse the kind of non-linear growth that will make the country one of the world’s top three economies and bring it closer to developed nation status by 2047.  The government has identified research, innovation and technology as the key drivers of its VisionIndia@2047 and is making significant investments in these areas. Going forward, it must enable and support innovative start-ups and businesses that think locally but have the potential to make an enormous global impact. By encouraging technopreneurs to grow from small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to large industrial-scale operations, India will be able to create a compelling opportunity to take innovative ideas to global markets. We should aim to be among the top 20 countries in the Global Innovation Index by 2047. Digital and data-backed innovation combined with ubiquitous and affordable internet will help India build a robust digital economy of the future.  Given India’s value advantage and scientific excellence, the country can innovate and drive the technology frontier outward to boost productivity and efficiency in the sphere of healthcare, thus delivering affordability and accessibility, enabling preventive health approaches and driving value across the complete spectrum of the healthcare ecosystem. Technology-led innovations will help India leapfrog the traditional linear model and take healthcare to the next level. It will help us build a national healthcare system, which is accessible, organised, accountable, affordable and, thus, resilient.  The groundwork for a digital transformation of healthcare in India has already been laid, thanks to the reforms being implemented by the Centre to make healthcare-related regulations more flexible. At the same time, the pandemic has forced changes in consumer behaviour, persuaded doctors to become tech-savvy and prompted the healthcare industry to invest in user-friendly digital solutions. These developments have created a fertile environment for the emergence of low-cost, technology-led and scalable innovations anchored in affordability and accessibility. To reap the full benefits of this digital disruption of healthcare, India will need to coordinate policymaking, funding and implementation. It will also need to put in place appropriate regulatory frameworks that foster patient trust and privacy, as well as enable faster adoption of emerging technological innovations.

questions.question_text_1: Read the following telephonic conversation and fill in the blank with appropriate responses for the given subquestions:   Arun: Good morning Ms.Girija! Class Teacher: Good morning! (i)_________________ Arun: I am Arun Srinivasan. I am the class monitor of the class of which you are the class teacher, 6E. Class Teacher: Oh yes, Arun! I could not recognise your voice. The audio (ii) ____________ Arun: Is the audio better now, ma’am? Class Teacher: Yes yes, tell me. (iii) _________________ Arun: Ma’am, I wanted to check your availability for scheduling the PTA meeting. (iv) __________ the slot from 2 PM, on the 28th of this month? Class Teacher: Let me check my schedule… Yes, I am free in that slot. You can confirm it. Arun: Thanks a lot, ma’am. I will schedule the meeting for that slot and send out an email to the class. Class Teacher: Sure, go ahead. (v) ______________ Arun? Arun: No ma’am. Thanks for your time! Class Teacher: You are welcome, Arun. See you on Monday.

questions.question_text_1: Context: A new development project is going to come up in your area that involves a lot of displacement of people. Different stakeholders with the project are stating their opinion on the various impacts, and the pros and cons of the project. Answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Context: A new development project is going to come up in your area that involves a lot of displacement of people. Different stakeholders with the project are stating their opinion on the various impacts, and the pros and cons of the project. Answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: A social activist is stating her opinion on this. The perspective she would choose is:
question_texts: A social activist is stating her opinion on this. The perspective she would choose is:

options.option_text: Giving refreshments to the construction workers
The problem of displacement of the people in the community

parent_question.question_text_1: Context: A new development project is going to come up in your area that involves a lot of displacement of people. questions.question_text_1: The project engineer is giving her opinion. Her perspective would be:
question_texts: The project engineer is giving her opinion. Her perspective would be:

options.option_text: The loss of open spaces for the community
The air pollution that will follow the construction
The human cost of the development project
The primary, secondary, and tertiary benefits of the project for the community

questions.question_text_1: A family that has been staying there for generations and has a shop in the vicinity is giving their opinion. Their perspective would be:
question_texts: A family that has been staying there for generations and has a shop in the vicinity is giving their opinion. Their perspective would be:

options.option_text: Neither Fear of displacement nor Loss of livelihood
Both Fear of displacement and Loss of livelihood

options.option_text: Hope for employment opportunities with the project
Concern for displacement of his friends and family
Both Hope for employment opportunities with the project and Concern fordisplacement of his friends and family
Neither Hope for employment opportunities with the project nor Concern fordisplacement of his friends and family

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Reading Comprehension
- **Core Topics**: Understanding and interpreting written passages, identifying key ideas, and answering questions based on the text.
- **Concepts**: Main idea, supporting details, vocabulary in context, inference, and summarization.
- **Principles**: Read the passage carefully, identify the main points, and use context clues to understand unfamiliar words.

#### Listening Comprehension
- **Core Topics**: Understanding spoken language, identifying key information, and answering questions based on audio samples.
- **Concepts**: Listening for main ideas, details, and specific information.
- **Principles**: Focus on the audio, take notes if necessary, and listen for key details.

#### Grammar and Vocabulary
- **Core Topics**: Parts of speech, phrasal verbs, idioms, articles, pronouns, verb forms, and prepositions.
- **Concepts**: Understanding the roles of different parts of speech, using appropriate articles and pronouns, and correctly forming verb tenses.
- **Principles**: Study grammar rules, practice using different parts of speech, and expand vocabulary through reading and listening.

#### Telephonic Conversations
- **Core Topics**: Appropriate responses in telephonic conversations, understanding context, and filling in blanks.
- **Concepts**: Politeness, clarity, and context-appropriate responses.
- **Principles**: Practice common telephonic conversations, focus on clarity and politeness, and understand the context of the conversation.

#### Word Collocation
- **Core Topics**: Matching words that commonly go together.
- **Concepts**: Understanding common word pairs and their usage.
- **Principles**: Study common word collocations, practice matching exercises, and read extensively to see words in context.

#### Stakeholder Perspectives
- **Core Topics**: Understanding different perspectives on a development project.
- **Concepts**: Identifying and understanding the viewpoints of various stakeholders.
- **Principles**: Consider the roles and interests of different stakeholders, and practice analyzing situations from multiple perspectives.

#### Phonetics
- **Core Topics**: Understanding sounds, semi-vowels, and vowel production.
- **Concepts**: Aspirated and non-aspirated sounds, voiced and non-voiced sounds, monophthongs, and diphthongs.
- **Principles**: Study phonetic symbols and their sounds, practice pronunciation, and understand the mechanics of sound production.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[English I] --> B[Reading Comprehension]
    A --> C[Listening Comprehension]
    A --> D[Grammar and Vocabulary]
    A --> E[Telephonic Conversations]
    A --> F[Word Collocation]
    A --> G[Stakeholder Perspectives]
    A --> H[Phonetics]

    B --> B1[Main Idea]
    B --> B2[Supporting Details]
    B --> B3[Vocabulary in Context]
    B --> B4[Inference]
    B --> B5[Summarization]

    C --> C1[Main Ideas]
    C --> C2[Details]
    C --> C3[Specific Information]

    D --> D1[Parts of Speech]
    D --> D2[Phrasal Verbs]
    D --> D3[Idioms]
    D --> D4[Articles]
    D --> D5[Pronouns]
    D --> D6[Verb Forms]
    D --> D7[Prepositions]

    E --> E1[Politeness]
    E --> E2[Clarity]
    E --> E3[Context-Appropriate Responses]

    F --> F1[Common Word Pairs]
    F --> F2[Usage]

    G --> G1[Roles and Interests]
    G --> G2[Multiple Perspectives]

    H --> H1[Aspirated and Non-Aspirated Sounds]
    H --> H2[Voiced and Non-Voiced Sounds]
    H --> H3[Monophthongs and Diphthongs]
    H --> H4[Phonetic Symbols]
```

This knowledge graph visually maps the relationships between the core topics covered in the exam. Each core topic is broken down into subtopics to provide a clear and easy-to-understand format.
